questiontext.text:
Two sportsmen collide resulting in the femur of one being loaded in torsion, as indicated below, which shows the affected bone modelled as a hollow cylinder. The top surface of the cylinder has been rotated by $$\small\theta$$ = 4.3o relative to the bottom surface, so that the line AB in the unstrained bone has become ABI.


This figure shows a cylindrical bone loaded in torsion as indicated by the arrows (left). The length of the bone, L, is 0.46 m. On the right, the top surface of the bone is shown, in which the darkly shaded annulus is the end of a cylindrical element of radius, r, and wall thickness, dr.

Part A

What is the shear strain ($$\small\epsilon$$) in the bone at a distance r cm from the femur axis?

(Please give your answer correct to 2.d.p)

{1:NUMERICAL:=3.92:0.005#Good Job!!~*#Incorrect} x10-3

Part B

Assuming that deformation throughout the bone is elastic, which of the following equations correctly describes the strain energy, dW, stored in the bone, which has a shear modulus of E.{1:MCV:~


#Incorrect~=


#Good Job!~


#Incorrect~


#Incorrect}

Part C

Solve this differential equation to calculate the total strain energy stored in the bone, if E has a value of 3.9 GPa, and the bone has an outer radius, ro, of  0.024 m and a wall thickness, t, of  0.012 m.

(Please give your answer correct to 2.d.p)

{1:NUMERICAL:=11.67:0.005#Good Job!!~*#Incorrect} Joules

generalfeedback.text:
Part A

To calculate the shear strain ($$\epsilon$$) we must first calculate the extension.

This is equal to the circumference of a circle of radius r ($$2\pi r$$), multiplied by the number of shear revolutions occuring ($$\frac{\theta }{360}$$).

As strain is simply a ratio of extension to original length, the extension is divided by L. The resulting expression can be simplified to give:


$$\epsilon =\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}$$


Part B

Assuming that deformation is elastic throughout, the shear stress at any point will be given by the expression ($$E.\epsilon$$).

The amount of energy stored per unit volume of bone is equal to the integral of the stress/strain plot between the limits of the bone's unstrained position and strained positions, as follows:


$$\int _0^{\epsilon }\left(E.\epsilon \right).d\epsilon \:=\:E.\left[\frac{\epsilon ^2}{2}\right]_0^{\epsilon }=\:\frac{E}{2}\cdot \left(\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}\right)^2$$


Imagine that the cylinder of bone was unrolled and laid out flat, it would then be a rectangular cuboid with a volume of:


$$2\pi r.L.dr$$.


When this expression for volume is multiplied by the expression for energy stored per unit volume, the resulting expression for strain energy stored can be simplified to:


$$dW=\frac{\pi ^3.E.r^3}{L}\left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.dr$$


Part C

By the integrating this expression between the limits of ro and ro-t, we obtain the following expression for total strain energy stored in the bone:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2\cdot \int _{r_o-t}^{r_o}r^3.dr$$


Which gives a final expression of:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{4.L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.\left[r^4\right]_{r_o-t}^{r_o}$$


Which allows you to calculate the total strain energy stored given all of the parameters given in the question.

hint.text:
HINT

Remember that strain is simply the ratio of extension to original length.

Remember that the integral of a stress/strain plot will give you the work done on a material per unit volume. What is the volume of this hollow cylinder?

Integrate the expression in Part B between the limits of ro and (ro-t) to solve Part C.

Remember that the integral of a stress/strain plot will give you the work done on a material per unit volume. What is the volume of this hollow cylinder?

Integrate the expression in Part B between the limits of ro and (ro-t) to solve Part C.

questiontext.text:
Two sportsmen collide resulting in the femur of one being loaded in torsion, as indicated below, which shows the affected bone modelled as a hollow cylinder. The top surface of the cylinder has been rotated by $$\small\theta$$ = 3.7o relative to the bottom surface, so that the line AB in the unstrained bone has become ABI.


This figure shows a cylindrical bone loaded in torsion as indicated by the arrows (left). The length of the bone, L, is 0.53 m. On the right, the top surface of the bone is shown, in which the darkly shaded annulus is the end of a cylindrical element of radius, r, and wall thickness, dr.

Part A

What is the shear strain ($$\small\epsilon$$) in the bone at a distance r cm from the femur axis?

(Please give your answer correct to 2.d.p)

{1:NUMERICAL:=2.68:0.005#Good Job!!~*#Incorrect} x10-3

Part B

Assuming that deformation throughout the bone is elastic, which of the following equations correctly describes the strain energy, dW, stored in the bone, which has a shear modulus of E.{1:MCV:~


#Incorrect~


#Incorrect~=


#Good Job!~


#Incorrect}

Part C

Solve this differential equation to calculate the total strain energy stored in the bone, if E has a value of 4 GPa, and the bone has an outer radius, ro, of  0.022 m and a wall thickness, t, of  0.011 m.

(Please give your answer correct to 2.d.p)

{1:NUMERICAL:=5.43:0.005#Good Job!!~*#Incorrect} Joules

generalfeedback.text:
Part A

To calculate the shear strain ($$\epsilon$$) we must first calculate the extension.

This is equal to the circumference of a circle of radius r ($$2\pi r$$), multiplied by the number of shear revolutions occuring ($$\frac{\theta }{360}$$).

As strain is simply a ratio of extension to original length, the extension is divided by L. The resulting expression can be simplified to give:


$$\epsilon =\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}$$


Part B

Assuming that deformation is elastic throughout, the shear stress at any point will be given by the expression ($$E.\epsilon$$).

The amount of energy stored per unit volume of bone is equal to the integral of the stress/strain plot between the limits of the bone's unstrained position and strained positions, as follows:


$$\int _0^{\epsilon }\left(E.\epsilon \right).d\epsilon \:=\:E.\left[\frac{\epsilon ^2}{2}\right]_0^{\epsilon }=\:\frac{E}{2}\cdot \left(\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}\right)^2$$


Imagine that the cylinder of bone was unrolled and laid out flat, it would then be a rectangular cuboid with a volume of:


$$2\pi r.L.dr$$.


When this expression for volume is multiplied by the expression for energy stored per unit volume, the resulting expression for strain energy stored can be simplified to:


$$dW=\frac{\pi ^3.E.r^3}{L}\left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.dr$$


Part C

By the integrating this expression between the limits of ro and ro-t, we obtain the following expression for total strain energy stored in the bone:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2\cdot \int _{r_o-t}^{r_o}r^3.dr$$


Which gives a final expression of:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{4.L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.\left[r^4\right]_{r_o-t}^{r_o}$$


Which allows you to calculate the total strain energy stored given all of the parameters given in the question.

hint.text:
HINT

Remember that strain is simply the ratio of extension to original length.

Remember that the integral of a stress/strain plot will give you the work done on a material per unit volume. What is the volume of this hollow cylinder?

Integrate the expression in Part B between the limits of ro and (ro-t) to solve Part C.

$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{4.L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.\left[r^4\right]_{r_o-t}^{r_o}$$


Which allows you to calculate the total strain energy stored given all of the parameters given in the question.

Two sportsmen collide resulting in the femur of one being loaded in torsion, as indicated below, which shows the affected bone modelled as a hollow cylinder. The top surface of the cylinder has been rotated by $$\small\theta$$ = 6.8o relative to the bottom surface, so that the line AB in the unstrained bone has become ABI.


This figure shows a cylindrical bone loaded in torsion as indicated by the arrows (left). The length of the bone, L, is 0.51 m. On the right, the top surface of the bone is shown, in which the darkly shaded annulus is the end of a cylindrical element of radius, r, and wall thickness, dr.

Part A

What is the shear strain ($$\small\epsilon$$) in the bone at a distance r cm from the femur axis?

(Please give your answer correct to 2.d.p)

#Incorrect~


#Incorrect~=


#Good Job!~


#Incorrect}

Part C

Solve this differential equation to calculate the total strain energy stored in the bone, if E has a value of 2.1 GPa, and the bone has an outer radius, ro, of  0.035 m and a wall thickness, t, of  0.0175 m.

(Please give your answer correct to 2.d.p)

{1:NUMERICAL:=64.08:0.005#Good Job!!~*#Incorrect} Joules

generalfeedback.text:
Part A

To calculate the shear strain ($$\epsilon$$) we must first calculate the extension.

This is equal to the circumference of a circle of radius r ($$2\pi r$$), multiplied by the number of shear revolutions occuring ($$\frac{\theta }{360}$$).

As strain is simply a ratio of extension to original length, the extension is divided by L. The resulting expression can be simplified to give:


$$\epsilon =\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}$$


Part B

Assuming that deformation is elastic throughout, the shear stress at any point will be given by the expression ($$E.\epsilon$$).

The amount of energy stored per unit volume of bone is equal to the integral of the stress/strain plot between the limits of the bone's unstrained position and strained positions, as follows:


$$\int _0^{\epsilon }\left(E.\epsilon \right).d\epsilon \:=\:E.\left[\frac{\epsilon ^2}{2}\right]_0^{\epsilon }=\:\frac{E}{2}\cdot \left(\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}\right)^2$$


Imagine that the cylinder of bone was unrolled and laid out flat, it would then be a rectangular cuboid with a volume of:


$$2\pi r.L.dr$$.


When this expression for volume is multiplied by the expression for energy stored per unit volume, the resulting expression for strain energy stored can be simplified to:


$$dW=\frac{\pi ^3.E.r^3}{L}\left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.dr$$


Part C

By the integrating this expression between the limits of ro and ro-t, we obtain the following expression for total strain energy stored in the bone:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2\cdot \int _{r_o-t}^{r_o}r^3.dr$$


Which gives a final expression of:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{4.L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.\left[r^4\right]_{r_o-t}^{r_o}$$


Which allows you to calculate the total strain energy stored given all of the parameters given in the question.

$$dW=\frac{\pi ^3.E.r^3}{L}\left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.dr$$


Part C

By the integrating this expression between the limits of ro and ro-t, we obtain the following expression for total strain energy stored in the bone:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2\cdot \int _{r_o-t}^{r_o}r^3.dr$$


Which gives a final expression of:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{4.L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.\left[r^4\right]_{r_o-t}^{r_o}$$


Which allows you to calculate the total strain energy stored given all of the parameters given in the question.

(Please give your answer correct to 2.d.p)

{1:NUMERICAL:=26.67:0.005#Good Job!!~*#Incorrect} Joules

generalfeedback.text:
Part A

To calculate the shear strain ($$\epsilon$$) we must first calculate the extension.

This is equal to the circumference of a circle of radius r ($$2\pi r$$), multiplied by the number of shear revolutions occuring ($$\frac{\theta }{360}$$).

As strain is simply a ratio of extension to original length, the extension is divided by L. The resulting expression can be simplified to give:


$$\epsilon =\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}$$


Part B

Assuming that deformation is elastic throughout, the shear stress at any point will be given by the expression ($$E.\epsilon$$).

The amount of energy stored per unit volume of bone is equal to the integral of the stress/strain plot between the limits of the bone's unstrained position and strained positions, as follows:


$$\int _0^{\epsilon }\left(E.\epsilon \right).d\epsilon \:=\:E.\left[\frac{\epsilon ^2}{2}\right]_0^{\epsilon }=\:\frac{E}{2}\cdot \left(\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}\right)^2$$


Imagine that the cylinder of bone was unrolled and laid out flat, it would then be a rectangular cuboid with a volume of:


$$2\pi r.L.dr$$.


When this expression for volume is multiplied by the expression for energy stored per unit volume, the resulting expression for strain energy stored can be simplified to:


$$dW=\frac{\pi ^3.E.r^3}{L}\left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.dr$$


Part C

By the integrating this expression between the limits of ro and ro-t, we obtain the following expression for total strain energy stored in the bone:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2\cdot \int _{r_o-t}^{r_o}r^3.dr$$


Which gives a final expression of:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{4.L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.\left[r^4\right]_{r_o-t}^{r_o}$$


Which allows you to calculate the total strain energy stored given all of the parameters given in the question.

$$\int _0^{\epsilon }\left(E.\epsilon \right).d\epsilon \:=\:E.\left[\frac{\epsilon ^2}{2}\right]_0^{\epsilon }=\:\frac{E}{2}\cdot \left(\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}\right)^2$$


Imagine that the cylinder of bone was unrolled and laid out flat, it would then be a rectangular cuboid with a volume of:


$$2\pi r.L.dr$$.


When this expression for volume is multiplied by the expression for energy stored per unit volume, the resulting expression for strain energy stored can be simplified to:


$$dW=\frac{\pi ^3.E.r^3}{L}\left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.dr$$


Part C

By the integrating this expression between the limits of ro and ro-t, we obtain the following expression for total strain energy stored in the bone:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2\cdot \int _{r_o-t}^{r_o}r^3.dr$$


Which gives a final expression of:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{4.L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.\left[r^4\right]_{r_o-t}^{r_o}$$


Which allows you to calculate the total strain energy stored given all of the parameters given in the question.

hint.text:

Remember that the integral of a stress/strain plot will give you the work done on a material per unit volume. What is the volume of this hollow cylinder?

Integrate the expression in Part B between the limits of ro and (ro-t) to solve Part C.

As strain is simply a ratio of extension to original length, the extension is divided by L. The resulting expression can be simplified to give:


$$\epsilon =\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}$$


Part B

Assuming that deformation is elastic throughout, the shear stress at any point will be given by the expression ($$E.\epsilon$$).

The amount of energy stored per unit volume of bone is equal to the integral of the stress/strain plot between the limits of the bone's unstrained position and strained positions, as follows:


$$\int _0^{\epsilon }\left(E.\epsilon \right).d\epsilon \:=\:E.\left[\frac{\epsilon ^2}{2}\right]_0^{\epsilon }=\:\frac{E}{2}\cdot \left(\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}\right)^2$$


Imagine that the cylinder of bone was unrolled and laid out flat, it would then be a rectangular cuboid with a volume of:


$$2\pi r.L.dr$$.


When this expression for volume is multiplied by the expression for energy stored per unit volume, the resulting expression for strain energy stored can be simplified to:


$$dW=\frac{\pi ^3.E.r^3}{L}\left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.dr$$


Part C

By the integrating this expression between the limits of ro and ro-t, we obtain the following expression for total strain energy stored in the bone:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2\cdot \int _{r_o-t}^{r_o}r^3.dr$$


Which gives a final expression of:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{4.L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.\left[r^4\right]_{r_o-t}^{r_o}$$


Which allows you to calculate the total strain energy stored given all of the parameters given in the question.

hint.text:
HINT

Remember that strain is simply the ratio of extension to original length.

Remember that the integral of a stress/strain plot will give you the work done on a material per unit volume. What is the volume of this hollow cylinder?

Integrate the expression in Part B between the limits of ro and (ro-t) to solve Part C.

{1:NUMERICAL:=47.22:0.005#Good Job!!~*#Incorrect} Joules

generalfeedback.text:
Part A

To calculate the shear strain ($$\epsilon$$) we must first calculate the extension.

This is equal to the circumference of a circle of radius r ($$2\pi r$$), multiplied by the number of shear revolutions occuring ($$\frac{\theta }{360}$$).

As strain is simply a ratio of extension to original length, the extension is divided by L. The resulting expression can be simplified to give:


$$\epsilon =\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}$$


Part B

Assuming that deformation is elastic throughout, the shear stress at any point will be given by the expression ($$E.\epsilon$$).

The amount of energy stored per unit volume of bone is equal to the integral of the stress/strain plot between the limits of the bone's unstrained position and strained positions, as follows:


$$\int _0^{\epsilon }\left(E.\epsilon \right).d\epsilon \:=\:E.\left[\frac{\epsilon ^2}{2}\right]_0^{\epsilon }=\:\frac{E}{2}\cdot \left(\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}\right)^2$$


Imagine that the cylinder of bone was unrolled and laid out flat, it would then be a rectangular cuboid with a volume of:


$$2\pi r.L.dr$$.


When this expression for volume is multiplied by the expression for energy stored per unit volume, the resulting expression for strain energy stored can be simplified to:


$$dW=\frac{\pi ^3.E.r^3}{L}\left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.dr$$


Part C

By the integrating this expression between the limits of ro and ro-t, we obtain the following expression for total strain energy stored in the bone:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2\cdot \int _{r_o-t}^{r_o}r^3.dr$$


Which gives a final expression of:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{4.L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.\left[r^4\right]_{r_o-t}^{r_o}$$


Which allows you to calculate the total strain energy stored given all of the parameters given in the question.

hint.text:
HINT

Remember that strain is simply the ratio of extension to original length.

Remember that the integral of a stress/strain plot will give you the work done on a material per unit volume. What is the volume of this hollow cylinder?

Integrate the expression in Part B between the limits of ro and (ro-t) to solve Part C.

#Incorrect~

Part C

Solve this differential equation to calculate the total strain energy stored in the bone, if E has a value of 2.4 GPa, and the bone has an outer radius, ro, of  0.026 m and a wall thickness, t, of  0.013 m.

(Please give your answer correct to 2.d.p)

{1:NUMERICAL:=11.85:0.005#Good Job!!~*#Incorrect} Joules

generalfeedback.text:
Part A

To calculate the shear strain ($$\epsilon$$) we must first calculate the extension.

This is equal to the circumference of a circle of radius r ($$2\pi r$$), multiplied by the number of shear revolutions occuring ($$\frac{\theta }{360}$$).

As strain is simply a ratio of extension to original length, the extension is divided by L. The resulting expression can be simplified to give:


$$\epsilon =\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}$$


Part B

Assuming that deformation is elastic throughout, the shear stress at any point will be given by the expression ($$E.\epsilon$$).

The amount of energy stored per unit volume of bone is equal to the integral of the stress/strain plot between the limits of the bone's unstrained position and strained positions, as follows:


$$\int _0^{\epsilon }\left(E.\epsilon \right).d\epsilon \:=\:E.\left[\frac{\epsilon ^2}{2}\right]_0^{\epsilon }=\:\frac{E}{2}\cdot \left(\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}\right)^2$$


Imagine that the cylinder of bone was unrolled and laid out flat, it would then be a rectangular cuboid with a volume of:


$$2\pi r.L.dr$$.


When this expression for volume is multiplied by the expression for energy stored per unit volume, the resulting expression for strain energy stored can be simplified to:


$$dW=\frac{\pi ^3.E.r^3}{L}\left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.dr$$


Part C

By the integrating this expression between the limits of ro and ro-t, we obtain the following expression for total strain energy stored in the bone:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2\cdot \int _{r_o-t}^{r_o}r^3.dr$$


Which gives a final expression of:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{4.L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.\left[r^4\right]_{r_o-t}^{r_o}$$


Which allows you to calculate the total strain energy stored given all of the parameters given in the question.

hint.text:
HINT

Remember that strain is simply the ratio of extension to original length.

Remember that the integral of a stress/strain plot will give you the work done on a material per unit volume. What is the volume of this hollow cylinder?

Integrate the expression in Part B between the limits of ro and (ro-t) to solve Part C.

What is the shear strain ($$\small\epsilon$$) in the bone at a distance r cm from the femur axis?

(Please give your answer correct to 2.d.p)

{1:NUMERICAL:=4.2:0.005#Good Job!!~*#Incorrect} x10-3

Part B

Assuming that deformation throughout the bone is elastic, which of the following equations correctly describes the strain energy, dW, stored in the bone, which has a shear modulus of E.{1:MCV:~


#Incorrect~


#Incorrect~


#Incorrect~=


#Good Job!}

Part C

Solve this differential equation to calculate the total strain energy stored in the bone, if E has a value of 3.6 GPa, and the bone has an outer radius, ro, of  0.02 m and a wall thickness, t, of  0.01 m.

(Please give your answer correct to 2.d.p)

{1:NUMERICAL:=9.18:0.005#Good Job!!~*#Incorrect} Joules

generalfeedback.text:
Part A

To calculate the shear strain ($$\epsilon$$) we must first calculate the extension.

This is equal to the circumference of a circle of radius r ($$2\pi r$$), multiplied by the number of shear revolutions occuring ($$\frac{\theta }{360}$$).

As strain is simply a ratio of extension to original length, the extension is divided by L. The resulting expression can be simplified to give:


$$\epsilon =\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}$$


Part B

Assuming that deformation is elastic throughout, the shear stress at any point will be given by the expression ($$E.\epsilon$$).

The amount of energy stored per unit volume of bone is equal to the integral of the stress/strain plot between the limits of the bone's unstrained position and strained positions, as follows:


$$\int _0^{\epsilon }\left(E.\epsilon \right).d\epsilon \:=\:E.\left[\frac{\epsilon ^2}{2}\right]_0^{\epsilon }=\:\frac{E}{2}\cdot \left(\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}\right)^2$$


Imagine that the cylinder of bone was unrolled and laid out flat, it would then be a rectangular cuboid with a volume of:


$$2\pi r.L.dr$$.


When this expression for volume is multiplied by the expression for energy stored per unit volume, the resulting expression for strain energy stored can be simplified to:


$$dW=\frac{\pi ^3.E.r^3}{L}\left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.dr$$


Part C

By the integrating this expression between the limits of ro and ro-t, we obtain the following expression for total strain energy stored in the bone:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2\cdot \int _{r_o-t}^{r_o}r^3.dr$$


Which gives a final expression of:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{4.L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.\left[r^4\right]_{r_o-t}^{r_o}$$


Which allows you to calculate the total strain energy stored given all of the parameters given in the question.

hint.text:
HINT

Remember that strain is simply the ratio of extension to original length.

Remember that the integral of a stress/strain plot will give you the work done on a material per unit volume. What is the volume of this hollow cylinder?

Integrate the expression in Part B between the limits of ro and (ro-t) to solve Part C.

The top surface of the cylinder has been rotated by $$\small\theta$$ = 5.9o relative to the bottom surface, so that the line AB in the unstrained bone has become ABI.


This figure shows a cylindrical bone loaded in torsion as indicated by the arrows (left). The length of the bone, L, is 0.47 m. On the right, the top surface of the bone is shown, in which the darkly shaded annulus is the end of a cylindrical element of radius, r, and wall thickness, dr.

Part A

What is the shear strain ($$\small\epsilon$$) in the bone at a distance r cm from the femur axis?

(Please give your answer correct to 2.d.p)

{1:NUMERICAL:=8.76:0.005#Good Job!!~*#Incorrect} x10-3

Part B

Assuming that deformation throughout the bone is elastic, which of the following equations correctly describes the strain energy, dW, stored in the bone, which has a shear modulus of E.{1:MCV:~


#Incorrect~=


#Good Job!~


#Incorrect~


#Incorrect}

Part C

Solve this differential equation to calculate the total strain energy stored in the bone, if E has a value of 3.4 GPa, and the bone has an outer radius, ro, of  0.04 m and a wall thickness, t, of  0.02 m.

(Please give your answer correct to 2.d.p)

{1:NUMERICAL:=144.59:0.005#Good Job!!~*#Incorrect} Joules

generalfeedback.text:
Part A

To calculate the shear strain ($$\epsilon$$) we must first calculate the extension.

This is equal to the circumference of a circle of radius r ($$2\pi r$$), multiplied by the number of shear revolutions occuring ($$\frac{\theta }{360}$$).

As strain is simply a ratio of extension to original length, the extension is divided by L. The resulting expression can be simplified to give:


$$\epsilon =\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}$$


Part B

Assuming that deformation is elastic throughout, the shear stress at any point will be given by the expression ($$E.\epsilon$$).

The amount of energy stored per unit volume of bone is equal to the integral of the stress/strain plot between the limits of the bone's unstrained position and strained positions, as follows:


$$\int _0^{\epsilon }\left(E.\epsilon \right).d\epsilon \:=\:E.\left[\frac{\epsilon ^2}{2}\right]_0^{\epsilon }=\:\frac{E}{2}\cdot \left(\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}\right)^2$$


Imagine that the cylinder of bone was unrolled and laid out flat, it would then be a rectangular cuboid with a volume of:


$$2\pi r.L.dr$$.


When this expression for volume is multiplied by the expression for energy stored per unit volume, the resulting expression for strain energy stored can be simplified to:


$$dW=\frac{\pi ^3.E.r^3}{L}\left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.dr$$


Part C

By the integrating this expression between the limits of ro and ro-t, we obtain the following expression for total strain energy stored in the bone:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2\cdot \int _{r_o-t}^{r_o}r^3.dr$$


Which gives a final expression of:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{4.L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.\left[r^4\right]_{r_o-t}^{r_o}$$


Which allows you to calculate the total strain energy stored given all of the parameters given in the question.

hint.text:
HINT

Remember that strain is simply the ratio of extension to original length.

Remember that the integral of a stress/strain plot will give you the work done on a material per unit volume. What is the volume of this hollow cylinder?

Integrate the expression in Part B between the limits of ro and (ro-t) to solve Part C.

Remember that the integral of a stress/strain plot will give you the work done on a material per unit volume. What is the volume of this hollow cylinder?

Integrate the expression in Part B between the limits of ro and (ro-t) to solve Part C.

questiontext.text:
Two sportsmen collide resulting in the femur of one being loaded in torsion, as indicated below, which shows the affected bone modelled as a hollow cylinder. The top surface of the cylinder has been rotated by $$\small\theta$$ = 6.1o relative to the bottom surface, so that the line AB in the unstrained bone has become ABI.


This figure shows a cylindrical bone loaded in torsion as indicated by the arrows (left). The length of the bone, L, is 0.49 m. On the right, the top surface of the bone is shown, in which the darkly shaded annulus is the end of a cylindrical element of radius, r, and wall thickness, dr.

Part A

What is the shear strain ($$\small\epsilon$$) in the bone at a distance r cm from the femur axis?

(Please give your answer correct to 2.d.p)

{1:NUMERICAL:=6.08:0.005#Good Job!!~*#Incorrect} x10-3

Part B

Assuming that deformation throughout the bone is elastic, which of the following equations correctly describes the strain energy, dW, stored in the bone, which has a shear modulus of E.{1:MCV:~


#Incorrect~


#Incorrect~=


#Good Job!~


#Incorrect}

Part C

Solve this differential equation to calculate the total strain energy stored in the bone, if E has a value of 3.3 GPa, and the bone has an outer radius, ro, of  0.028 m and a wall thickness, t, of  0.014 m.

(Please give your answer correct to 2.d.p)

{1:NUMERICAL:=34.55:0.005#Good Job!!~*#Incorrect} Joules

generalfeedback.text:
Part A

To calculate the shear strain ($$\epsilon$$) we must first calculate the extension.

This is equal to the circumference of a circle of radius r ($$2\pi r$$), multiplied by the number of shear revolutions occuring ($$\frac{\theta }{360}$$).

As strain is simply a ratio of extension to original length, the extension is divided by L. The resulting expression can be simplified to give:


$$\epsilon =\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}$$


Part B

Assuming that deformation is elastic throughout, the shear stress at any point will be given by the expression ($$E.\epsilon$$).

The amount of energy stored per unit volume of bone is equal to the integral of the stress/strain plot between the limits of the bone's unstrained position and strained positions, as follows:


$$\int _0^{\epsilon }\left(E.\epsilon \right).d\epsilon \:=\:E.\left[\frac{\epsilon ^2}{2}\right]_0^{\epsilon }=\:\frac{E}{2}\cdot \left(\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}\right)^2$$


Imagine that the cylinder of bone was unrolled and laid out flat, it would then be a rectangular cuboid with a volume of:


$$2\pi r.L.dr$$.


When this expression for volume is multiplied by the expression for energy stored per unit volume, the resulting expression for strain energy stored can be simplified to:


$$dW=\frac{\pi ^3.E.r^3}{L}\left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.dr$$


Part C

By the integrating this expression between the limits of ro and ro-t, we obtain the following expression for total strain energy stored in the bone:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2\cdot \int _{r_o-t}^{r_o}r^3.dr$$


Which gives a final expression of:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{4.L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.\left[r^4\right]_{r_o-t}^{r_o}$$


Which allows you to calculate the total strain energy stored given all of the parameters given in the question.

hint.text:
HINT

Remember that strain is simply the ratio of extension to original length.

Remember that the integral of a stress/strain plot will give you the work done on a material per unit volume. What is the volume of this hollow cylinder?

Integrate the expression in Part B between the limits of ro and (ro-t) to solve Part C.

$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{4.L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.\left[r^4\right]_{r_o-t}^{r_o}$$


Which allows you to calculate the total strain energy stored given all of the parameters given in the question.

Two sportsmen collide resulting in the femur of one being loaded in torsion, as indicated below, which shows the affected bone modelled as a hollow cylinder. The top surface of the cylinder has been rotated by $$\small\theta$$ = 7.5o relative to the bottom surface, so that the line AB in the unstrained bone has become ABI.


This figure shows a cylindrical bone loaded in torsion as indicated by the arrows (left). The length of the bone, L, is 0.5 m. On the right, the top surface of the bone is shown, in which the darkly shaded annulus is the end of a cylindrical element of radius, r, and wall thickness, dr.

Part A

What is the shear strain ($$\small\epsilon$$) in the bone at a distance r cm from the femur axis?

Solve this differential equation to calculate the total strain energy stored in the bone, if E has a value of 3.3 GPa, and the bone has an outer radius, ro, of  0.036 m and a wall thickness, t, of  0.018 m.

(Please give your answer correct to 2.d.p)

{1:NUMERICAL:=139.86:0.005#Good Job!!~*#Incorrect} Joules

generalfeedback.text:
Part A

To calculate the shear strain ($$\epsilon$$) we must first calculate the extension.

This is equal to the circumference of a circle of radius r ($$2\pi r$$), multiplied by the number of shear revolutions occuring ($$\frac{\theta }{360}$$).

As strain is simply a ratio of extension to original length, the extension is divided by L. The resulting expression can be simplified to give:


$$\epsilon =\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}$$


Part B

Assuming that deformation is elastic throughout, the shear stress at any point will be given by the expression ($$E.\epsilon$$).

The amount of energy stored per unit volume of bone is equal to the integral of the stress/strain plot between the limits of the bone's unstrained position and strained positions, as follows:


$$\int _0^{\epsilon }\left(E.\epsilon \right).d\epsilon \:=\:E.\left[\frac{\epsilon ^2}{2}\right]_0^{\epsilon }=\:\frac{E}{2}\cdot \left(\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}\right)^2$$


Imagine that the cylinder of bone was unrolled and laid out flat, it would then be a rectangular cuboid with a volume of:


$$2\pi r.L.dr$$.


When this expression for volume is multiplied by the expression for energy stored per unit volume, the resulting expression for strain energy stored can be simplified to:


$$dW=\frac{\pi ^3.E.r^3}{L}\left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.dr$$


Part C

By the integrating this expression between the limits of ro and ro-t, we obtain the following expression for total strain energy stored in the bone:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2\cdot \int _{r_o-t}^{r_o}r^3.dr$$


Which gives a final expression of:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{4.L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.\left[r^4\right]_{r_o-t}^{r_o}$$


Which allows you to calculate the total strain energy stored given all of the parameters given in the question.

Part C

By the integrating this expression between the limits of ro and ro-t, we obtain the following expression for total strain energy stored in the bone:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2\cdot \int _{r_o-t}^{r_o}r^3.dr$$


Which gives a final expression of:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{4.L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.\left[r^4\right]_{r_o-t}^{r_o}$$


Which allows you to calculate the total strain energy stored given all of the parameters given in the question.

hint.text:
HINT

Remember that strain is simply the ratio of extension to original length.

Remember that the integral of a stress/strain plot will give you the work done on a material per unit volume. What is the volume of this hollow cylinder?

Integrate the expression in Part B between the limits of ro and (ro-t) to solve Part C.

questiontext.text:
Two sportsmen collide resulting in the femur of one being loaded in torsion, as indicated below, which shows the affected bone modelled as a hollow cylinder. The top surface of the cylinder has been rotated by $$\small\theta$$ = 3.2o relative to the bottom surface, so that the line AB in the unstrained bone has become ABI.


This figure shows a cylindrical bone loaded in torsion as indicated by the arrows (left). The length of the bone, L, is 0.51 m. On the right, the top surface of the bone is shown, in which the darkly shaded annulus is the end of a cylindrical element of radius, r, and wall thickness, dr.

Part A

What is the shear strain ($$\small\epsilon$$) in the bone at a distance r cm from the femur axis?

(Please give your answer correct to 2.d.p)

{1:NUMERICAL:=3.72:0.005#Good Job!!~*#Incorrect} x10-3

Part B

Assuming that deformation throughout the bone is elastic, which of the following equations correctly describes the strain energy, dW, stored in the bone, which has a shear modulus of E.{1:MCV:~


#Incorrect~


#Incorrect~


#Incorrect~=


#Good Job!}

Part C

Solve this differential equation to calculate the total strain energy stored in the bone, if E has a value of 2.7 GPa, and the bone has an outer radius, ro, of  0.034 m and a wall thickness, t, of  0.017 m.

(Please give your answer correct to 2.d.p)

{1:NUMERICAL:=16.25:0.005#Good Job!!~*#Incorrect} Joules

generalfeedback.text:
Part A

To calculate the shear strain ($$\epsilon$$) we must first calculate the extension.

This is equal to the circumference of a circle of radius r ($$2\pi r$$), multiplied by the number of shear revolutions occuring ($$\frac{\theta }{360}$$).

As strain is simply a ratio of extension to original length, the extension is divided by L. The resulting expression can be simplified to give:


$$\epsilon =\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}$$


Part B

Assuming that deformation is elastic throughout, the shear stress at any point will be given by the expression ($$E.\epsilon$$).

The amount of energy stored per unit volume of bone is equal to the integral of the stress/strain plot between the limits of the bone's unstrained position and strained positions, as follows:


$$\int _0^{\epsilon }\left(E.\epsilon \right).d\epsilon \:=\:E.\left[\frac{\epsilon ^2}{2}\right]_0^{\epsilon }=\:\frac{E}{2}\cdot \left(\frac{\pi .r.\theta }{180.L}\right)^2$$


Imagine that the cylinder of bone was unrolled and laid out flat, it would then be a rectangular cuboid with a volume of:


$$2\pi r.L.dr$$.


When this expression for volume is multiplied by the expression for energy stored per unit volume, the resulting expression for strain energy stored can be simplified to:


$$dW=\frac{\pi ^3.E.r^3}{L}\left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.dr$$


Part C

By the integrating this expression between the limits of ro and ro-t, we obtain the following expression for total strain energy stored in the bone:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2\cdot \int _{r_o-t}^{r_o}r^3.dr$$


Which gives a final expression of:


$$W=\frac{\pi ^3.E}{4.L}\cdot \left(\frac{\theta }{180}\right)^2.\left[r^4\right]_{r_o-t}^{r_o}$$


Which allows you to calculate the total strain energy stored given all of the parameters given in the question.

Remember that the integral of a stress/strain plot will give you the work done on a material per unit volume. What is the volume of this hollow cylinder?
